statics.name: grammar
statics.example:
rg = RiTa.grammar();
rg.addRule("start", "( cat | dog | fish )");
let result = rg.expand();
statics.description:
Creates a new RiGrammar object: a probabilistic context-free grammar for text-generation. You may use any of the RiScript features in a RiTa grammar, including transforms, sequences, and assignments.

rg = new RiGrammar(theRules);
result = rg.expand();

RiTa grammars are valid JSON formatted strings (or JS objects or Java Maps), as follows

{
  "start": ( $rule1 | $rule2 | $rule3 ),

  "rule2": ( terminal1 | terminal2 | $rule1 ),

   ...
}

If you're working in JavaScript, you can alternatively just pass a JavaScript object instead. If you're not sure whether your grammar is valid JSON, check it at jsonlint.com.

Note: a RiGrammar object will assign (by default) equal weights to all choices in a rule. You can adjust the weights by adding 'multipliers' as described in the RiScript reference. For example, in the rule below 'terminal1' will be chosen twice as often as the two other choices.

rule2: ( terminal1 [2] | terminal2 | $rule1 )
statics.syntax:
// Initialize an empty RiGrammar object

rg = RiTa.grammar();


// Or specify a grammar in a JSON string (or JS object)

rg = RiTa.grammar(myJson);


// Or supply a context

rg = RiTa.grammar(myJson, context);

parameters.desc: A JSON string, a JS object, or a Java Map representing the grammar rules (optional)
A context object (or Map in Java), optional

returns.desc: a RiGrammar object

statics.name: markov
statics.example:
txt = "This is a two sentence example. This is the second one."

rm = RiTa.markov(3);
rm.addText(txt1);
rm.addText(txt2);
sentences = rm.generate(2);
statics.description:
Creates a new RiMarkov object with functions for text-generation, as well as a range of other probabilistic functions.

This object uses Markov chains (aka n-grams) with options to process words or arbitrary regular expressions.
statics.syntax:
// Constructs a RiMarkov object and set its n-factor.

RiTa.markov(nFactor);


// Create an object and specify one or more options

RiTa.markov(nFactor, options);

parameters.desc: n-factor - the length of each n-gram stored in the model

options for creating the model (optional)

{int} options.maxLengthMatch:
# of words allowed in result to match a sequence in the input, default=N+1

{boolean} options.disableInputChecks:
if true, allow result to be present in the input, default=false

{Function} options.tokenize:
a custom tokenize function to use, default=RiTa.tokenize

{Function} options.untokenize [JS only]:
a custom tokenize function to use, default=RiTa.untokenize

{boolean} options.trace:
if true, output debug log to console, default=false

{int} options.maxAttempts:
max attempts before throwing an error in generation, default=999

returns.desc: a RiMarkov object

statics.related: see the tutorial Generating with Markov chains

statics.name: tokens
statics.example:
sentence = "One dog is like the other dog.";
tokens = RiTa.tokens(sentence);

statics.description: Return an array containing all unique alphabetical words (tokens) in the text.

parameters.desc:
options (optional), the relevant options for the function:

{String or Regex} options.regex:
customized regex for the tokenization,

{boolean} options.splitContractions:
Convert contractions (e.g., "I'd" or "she'll") into multiple individual tokens

{boolean} options.includePunct:
Include punctuation tokens in the output

{boolean} options.caseSensitive:
Treat differently cased strings as separate tokens

{boolean} options.ignoreStopWords:
Ignore words like 'the', 'and', 'a', 'of', etc, as specified in RiTa.STOP_WORDS

{boolean} options.sort:
Return the results in sorted order

returns.desc: the set of unique alphabetical tokens in the text

statics.related:
RiTa.tokenize()
RiTa.SPLIT_CONTRACTIONS: boolean to globally control the splitting of contractions (e.g. splitting "I'd" or "she'll") into multiple individual tokens) default=false.

statics.name: tokenize
statics.example:
sentence = "The doctors treated dogs.";
words = RiTa.tokenize(sentence);

statics.description: Tokenizes a string (into words) according to the Penn Treebank conventions.

parameters.desc:
options (optional) the relevant options for the function:

{boolean} options.splitContractions:
Convert contractions (e.g., "I'd" or "she'll") into multiple individual tokens

{String or Regex} options.regex:
Customized regex for the tokenization

returns.desc: Array in which each element is a single token (generally a word or single punctuation character)

statics.relatedConstant: RiTa.SPLIT_CONTRACTIONS: boolean to globally control the splitting of contractions (e.g. splitting "I'd" or "she'll") into multiple individual tokens) default=false

statics.name: untokenize
statics.description: Joins an array (of words and punctuation) into a sentence, according to the Penn Treebank conventions. The inverse of RiTa.tokenize().

parameters.desc: the input, an array of words (tokens) and punctuation

returns.desc: String containing all elements as a sentence

Takes an string returns a combined string of the form:

statics.name: syllables
statics.description: Analyzes the input and returns a string containing the phonemes for each syllable of each word of the input text,  delimited by dashes (phonemes) and spaces (words)

returns.desc: e.g., 'dh-ax d-ao-g r-ae-n f-ae-s-t' for the 4 syllables of the phrase 'The dog ran fast'

statics.name: concordance
statics.example:
// Java

opts = new HashMap();
opts.put("ignoreCase", false);
opts.put("ignoreStopWords", true);

result = RiTa.concordance(text, opts);


// JavaScript

opts = {
ignoreCase: false,
ignoreStopWords: true
};

result = RiTa.concordance(text, opts);
statics.description: Creates a concordance, a list of words with their frequency of occurence, from the given text and options

parameters.desc:
options (optional) the relevant options for the KWIC model:

{boolean} options.ignoreCase:
Ignore upper/lower case in the model

{boolean} options.ignoreStopWords:
Ignore words like 'the', 'and', 'a', 'of', etc, as specified in RiTa.STOP_WORDS

{boolean} options.ignorePunctuation:
Ignore punctuation tokens in the model

{String[]} options.wordsToIgnore:
A set of words (alternative stop-words, for example) to ignore.

returns.desc: the concordance

statics.name: kwic
statics.example:
opts = {
ignoreCase: false,
ignoreStopWords: true
};

RiTa.concordance(text, opts);
lines = RiTa.kwic(word, numWords);
statics.description:
Return a list of occurrences of the key word in the Key-Word-In-Context (KWIC) model.

Note: RiTa.concordance() must called before calling kwic().
statics.syntax:
RiTa.kwic(word);
RiTa.kwic(word, numWords);
// in Java only
RiTa.kwic(word, options)

parameters.desc: upper limit of words before/after the keyword (optional, default=6)

options for the model and the output (optional)

{String} options.text:
the text as the input of the KWIC model, you can set this option instead of calling RiTa.concordance() before RiTa.kwic(), if this option is set, it will overwrite the existing KWIC model

{String} options.words:
the words as the input of the KWIC model, you can set this option instead of calling RiTa.concordance() before RiTa.kwic(), if this option is set, it will overwrite the exist KWIC model

{int} options.numWords:
another way to set the numWords

{others} others:
if options.text or options.words is set, you can also set other concordance options for the model, please see RiTa.concordance() for detail

returns.desc: all the occurrences of the keyword in the model, each with no more than 'numWords' words of context on either side

statics.name: conjugate
statics.example:
// JavaScript

opts = {
tense: RiTa.PRESENT,
number: RiTa.SINGULAR,
person: RiTa.THIRD
};

result = RiTa.conjugate('swim', opts);


// Java

opts = new HashMap();
opts.put("tense", RiTa.PAST);
opts.put("number", RiTa.PLURAL);
opts.put("person", RiTa.FIRST);

result = RiTa.conjugate("swim", opts);
statics.description: Conjugates the 'verb' according to the specified options

parameters.desc:
object containing the relevant options (tense, number, person...) for the conjugator

{int} options.tense:
[RiTa.PAST, RiTa.PRESENT, or RiTa.FUTURE]

{int} options.number:
[RiTa.SINGULAR or RiTa.PLURAL]

{int} options.person:
[RiTa.FIRST, RiTa.SECOND or RiTa.THIRD]

{int} options.form:
[RiTa.INFINITIVE or RiTa.GERUND]

{boolean} options.passive

{boolean} options.progressive

{boolean} options.interrogative

{boolean} options.perfect

returns.desc: the conjugated verb

options (optional)

{int} options.maxLength:
maximum number of characters in target word

{int} options.numSyllables:
target # of syllables in the word

{int} options.limit:
maximum # of results to return (default=10)

{String} options.type:

statics.name: isAdverb
statics.description: Returns true if the word has an adverb form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of an adverb in the Penn tag set (e.g. rb, rbr, rbs)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as an adverb

statics.name: isNoun
statics.description: Returns true if the word has a noun form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of a noun in the Penn tag set(e.g. nn, nns, nnp, nnps)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as a noun

statics.name: isVerb
statics.description: Returns true for if word has a verb form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of a verb in the Penn tag set (e.g. vb, vbg, vbd, vbp, vbz)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as a verb

statics.name: isStopWord
statics.description: Returns true if the word is a 'stop word', a commonly used word that is often ignored in text processing. To use your own list, set RiTa.STOP_WORDS to a new array of (lowercase) words.

returns.desc: true if the word is a stop word, according to RiTa.STOP_WORDS

statics.name: isAdjective
statics.description: Returns true if word has an adjective form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of an adjective in the Penn tag set (e.g. jj, jjr, jjs)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as an adjective

statics.name: isAlliteration
statics.description: Returns true if the two words are alliterations (if their first stressed consonants match). Note: returns true if wordA.equals(wordB) and false if either (or both) are null.

parameters.desc: (optional, only in Java) noLTS: if set to true the process will not use LTS (letter-to-sound rules), default=false

returns.desc: true if the first stressed consonant of the two words match

statics.name: isRhyme
statics.description:
Returns true if the two words rhyme, that is, if their final stressed vowel phoneme and all following phonemes are identical, else false.

Note: returns false if word1.equals(word2) or if either (or both) are null;

parameters.desc: (optional, only in Java) noLTS: if set to true the process will not use LTS (letter-to-sound rules), default=false

returns.desc: true if the two words rhyme, else false.

statics.name: soundsLike

RiTa.soundsLike("happy", { matchSpelling: true });
RiTa.soundsLike("happy", { limit: 10, minDistance: 2 });

RiTa.soundsLike("happy", { minWordLength:10, numSyllables:2 });
statics.description: Compares the phonemes of the input word (using a version of the Levenstein min-edit distance algorithm) to each word in the lexicon, returning the set of closest matches.

parameters.desc:
options (optional)

{bool} options.matchSpelling:
if true will also attempt to match spelling
by returning an intersection with RiTa.spellsLike (default=false)

{int} options.minLength:
minimum number of characters in target word (default=3)

{int} options.maxLength:
maximum number of characters in target word

{int} options.numSyllables:
target # of syllables in the word

{int} options.limit:
maximum # of results to return (default=10)

{String} options.pos:
the target part-of-speech for word in the result
either from the Penn tag set or the simplified tag set [a, r, v, n]

{int} options.minDistance:
the minimum distance of words from the target word
(increase to get more results)

returns.desc: the matching words
